block.p: Family Nature Hikes Inwood Hill Park; entrance at Indian Road and 218th Street, the Bronx; (718)788-8500. Sharon Seitz, author of the new ''Big Apple Safari for Families: The Urban Park Rangers' Guide to Nature in New York City'' (Countryman Press), a guide to activities like hiking, biking, bird-watching and fishing, will lead a 1.6-mile walk along trails in Inwood Hill Park on Saturday from 3 to 5 p.m.

Family Nature Hikes Inwood Hill Park; entrance at Indian Road and 218th Street, the Bronx; (718)788-8500. Sharon Seitz, author of the new ''Big Apple Safari for Families: The Urban Park Rangers' Guide to Nature in New York City'' (Countryman Press), a guide to activities like hiking, biking, bird-watching and fishing, will lead a 1.6-mile walk along trails in Inwood Hill Park on Saturday from 3 to 5 p.m.

Reservations are required for the hike, which is being sponsored by the Brooklyn Center for the Urban Environment. It is not recommended for children under 5. The fee is $11 for adults; children under 15 free.

Ms. Seitz will offer two other family hikes in the city. On July 30 from 10 a.m. to noon, there will be a walk in the Mount Loretto Nature Preserve on southern Staten Island, and on Aug. 6 from 10 a.m. to noon, a hike on the North 40 trail at Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn.
Reservations are required for both hikes: (718)369-9696. Participants should bring lunch. The fee for each is $5; children under 15 free.

New York Streets Municipal Art Society; (212)439-1049. The society will offer a series of walking tours starting on Sunday at 1 p.m. with a look at Art Deco architecture in downtown Manhattan, including the New York Telephone Company headquarters and the Irving Trust Tower at 1 Wall Street. Participants will meet at the Museum of the American Indian, on Bowling Green at the foot of Broadway.

Other tours will include Madison Square (July 29 at 11 a.m.); Jackson Heights (Aug. 6 at 11 a.m.) and Yorkville (Aug. 7 at 1 p.m.). The fee for tours from Monday through Friday is $12; Saturday and Sunday, $15. Information about meeting locations is available by phone or at mas.org.

Connecticut Houses Norfolk Historical Society and Museum, 13 Village Green (near Route 44), Norfolk, Conn.; (860)542-5761. The museum will offer a self-guided tour on Saturday of six houses designed by Alfredo S.G. Taylor (1872-1947) in Norfolk, including the architect's summer home as well as a 1907 house designed to look like a Bavarian hunting lodge and some of his early stone and stucco designs. The tour will be from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; tickets, $30.
Taylor was primarily a Beaux-Arts designer, but he drew on Arts and Crafts and Spanish colonial styles.
An exhibition of his work will be at the museum through Oct. 10. It is open Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 4 p.m. Free.
